alert.note: Alert for City and Borough of Juneau (Alaska) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued August 06 at 4:41AM AKDT by NWS Juneau
info.description: .Water levels on the Mendenhall are receding rapidly after reaching a record high crest. Flooding is ongoing as of 4 AM Sunday. ...FLOOD WARNING FOR A GLACIER-DAMMED LAKE OUTBURST REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 10 AM AKDT THIS MORNING... * WHAT...Flooding caused by a glacier-dammed lake outburst continues. * WHERE...All areas near the Mendenhall Lake and River. * WHEN...Until 1000 AM AKDT. * IMPACTS...Record high flooding has occurred and several feet of water was reported in areas near the river and in homes that have not previously seen flooding. Significant bank erosion is occurring with reports of structures and large trees collapsing into the river Saturday evening. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 421 AM AKDT, The water level of Mendenhall Lake crested at a record stage of 14.97 feet at 11:15 PM Saturday. This was above the Major Flood Stage of 14 feet and breaks the previous record of 11.99 feet set in 2016. - For Mendenhall Lake : At 4:15am the stage was 11.95 feet. Moderate Flood Stage is 10.0 feet. Forecast: Water levels will continue to recede rapidly through Sunday morning at a rate of around 0.7 foot per hour. Impacts: At 10.9 feet: View Drive will be flooded and impassable with significant flooding to some homes in the area. Locations below back loop bridge will begin to see flooding of some yards, significant bank erosion along with hazardous navigation from debris in the river. - Inherent uncertainty in initial glacier lake volume will result in varying crest height and timing. - If you live near or along the Mendenhall River, stay alert and be prepared to take action. - The US Coast Guard recommends that mariners use caution when transiting the affected area and be aware of significant debris in the water.
info.instruction: Stay tuned to further developments by listening to your local radio, television, or NOAA Weather Radio for further information. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Stay away or be swept away. River banks and culverts can become unstable and unsafe.
